questions.title: Curve Based and Empirical Fixed Income Risk Measures
questions.question:
For bonds that are otherwise identical, the one exhibiting the highest level of positive convexity is most likely the one that is:

  1. putable.
  2. callable.
  3. option-free.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. When interest rates rise, a putable bond is more likely to be put back to the issuer by the investor, limiting the loss of value and giving the bond more positive convexity than an option-free bond. In contrast, a callable bond is likely to be called from the investor when interest rates fall, limiting the gain in value and giving the bond negative convexity. Incorrect because a callable bond exhibits negative convexity. Incorrect because an option-free bond exhibits less positive convexity than a putable bond. Curve-Based and Empirical Fixed-Income Risk Measures explain why effective duration and effective convexity are the most appropriate measures of interest rate risk for bonds with embedded options
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. When interest rates rise, a putable bond is more likely to be put back to the issuer by the investor, limiting the loss of value and giving the bond more positive convexity than an option-free bond. In contrast, a callable bond is likely to be called from the investor when interest rates fall, limiting the gain in value and giving the bond negative convexity.

  2. Incorrect because a callable bond exhibits negative convexity.

  3. Incorrect because an option-free bond exhibits less positive convexity than a putable bond.

questions.title: Curve Based and Empirical Fixed Income Risk Measures
questions.question:
In a low interest rate environment, the effective duration of a callable bond relative to a comparable non-callable bond, will most likely be:

  1. lower.
  2. the same.
  3. higher.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. When interest rates are low, the callable bond‚Äôs price will not increase as much because the presence of the call option will limit the price increase. Because the bond is likely to be called when interest rates are falling, the embedded call option will reduce the effective duration of the bond. Incorrect because in a falling interest rate environment the effective duration of a callable bond will be lower than the effective duration of a comparable non-callable bond. Incorrect because in a falling interest rate environment the effective duration of a callable bond will be lower, not higher, than the effective duration of a comparable non-callable bond. questions.title: Curve Based and Empirical Fixed Income Risk Measures
questions.question:
Which of the following duration measures is the most appropriate measure of interest rate risk for a complex bond?

  1. Effective duration
  2. Modified duration
  3. Macaulay duration
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. A complex bond (such as a bond with an imbedded call option) does not have a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of the bond‚Äôs future cash flows, which depend on future interest rate changes. Because a complex bond‚Äôs yield to maturity is not well defined, yield duration measures such as Macaulay duration and modified duration are inappropriate measures of interest rate risk. Therefore, effective duration is the appropriate duration measure for a complex bond. Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration measure of the sensitivity of the bond price to the bond‚Äôs own, well-defined yield to maturity. Since a complex bond lacks a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of future cash flows, modified duration is not an appropriate measure of a complex bond‚Äôs interest rate risk. Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a yield duration measure of the sensitivity of the bond price to the bond‚Äôs own, well-defined yield to maturity. Since a complex bond lacks a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of future cash flows, Macaulay duration is not an appropriate measure of a complex bond‚Äôs interest rate risk. Curve-Based and Empirical Fixed-Income Risk Measures explain why effective duration and effective convexity are the most appropriate measures of interest rate risk for bonds with embedded options
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. A complex bond (such as a bond with an imbedded call option) does not have a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of the bond‚Äôs future cash flows, which depend on future interest rate changes. Because a complex bond‚Äôs yield to maturity is not well defined, yield duration measures such as Macaulay duration and modified duration are inappropriate measures of interest rate risk. Therefore, effective duration is the appropriate duration measure for a complex bond.

  2. Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration measure of the sensitivity of the bond price to the bond‚Äôs own, well-defined yield to maturity. Since a complex bond lacks a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of future cash flows, modified duration is not an appropriate measure of a complex bond‚Äôs interest rate risk.

  3. Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a yield duration measure of the sensitivity of the bond price to the bond‚Äôs own, well-defined yield to maturity. Since a complex bond lacks a well-defined yield to maturity because of the uncertainty of future cash flows, Macaulay duration is not an appropriate measure of a complex bond‚Äôs interest rate risk.

questions.title: Curve Based and Empirical Fixed Income Risk Measures
questions.question: What impact would a ‚Äúflight to safety‚Äù (i.e., government bond yields falling and credit spreads widening) have on the analytical duration estimate of Bond A?
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. There would be no impact on the analytical duration estimate. However, an empirical duration estimate would be impacted. A flight to safety would result in an increase in the bond price due to the falling benchmark yield being offset by widening credit spread. This would lead to a lower empirical duration than analytical duration.

Solution

C is correct. There would be no impact on the analytical duration estimate. However, an empirical duration estimate would be impacted.
